column7: Root for XBRL GL. No entry made here.
Parent for descriptive information about the accountingEntries section in which it is contained.

account: information to fill in a chart of accounts file.
balance: the results of accumulation of a complete and validated list of entries for an account (or a list of account) in a specific period - sometimes called general ledger
entries: a list of individual accounting entries, which might be posted/validated or nonposted/validated
journal: a self-balancing (Dr = Cr) list of entries for a specific period including beginning balance for that period.
ledger: a complete list of entries for a specific account (or list of accounts) for a specific period; note - debits do not have to equal credits.
assets: a listing of open receivables, payables, inventory, fixed assets or other information that can be extracted from but are not necessarily included as part of a journal entry.
trialBalance: the self-balancing (Dr = Cr) result of accumulation of a complete and validated list of entries for the entity in a complete list of accounts in a specific period.
taxtables: aids automated interpretation of instances that represent tax tables; Tax table are defined by using multiple [taxes] structures to gather the population of codes, authorities and rates; through [taxTableCode] cross-references in the [taxes] structure, these "master file" tax tables can be referenced. 
mapping: a collection of mappings between interrelated data sets, such as a local and related corporate standard chart of accounts or detail data mapped to summarized end reporting concepts.
versioning: a collection of changes between two versions of the same class of information, such as updates to a master file like a chart of accounts.  
master_file: a collection of master files, such as the customer or inventory master file. 
trade_documents: a collection of trade/transactional documents, such as vendor invoices or customer orders. 
profile_compliant: the meaning of this collection of information can be determined by understanding an established profile and especially an XBRL GL Profile. Profiles are determined through namespace declarations, schemaRef and conventions of those profiles.
other: for all other types of representations.
Often sorted by date or by account, these terms have specific, and sometimes different, meanings in different areas. Common practice will drive accounting method/term matches.
Unique identifier for this file.
Internal ID Number associated with identifierReference
Provides guidance on action to take with previous set of data: supersedes - old data should be considered as obsolete/overwritten; supplements - belongs with that data as if it was included with it.
Primary language of the intellectual content. Where practical, the content of this field should coincide with ISO 639-1988 language codes.
Date/time file was created.
Identifies the creator of the XBRL instance.
Text for entire document.
Start of date range for contents. Used as basis for many assumptions about data, including the date as of which open balances are open.
End of date range for contents. Used as basis for many assumptions about data, including the date as of which open balances are open.
Number of periods or buckets, used by postingCode. Used to interpret posting date. It may be preferable to limit entries by period covered to be by individual reporting period.
Type of periods covered by periodCount. Enumerated as: daily, weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, monthly, quarterly, thirdly, semiannual, annual, ad-hoc, current-period-only, other.
Free format description of the period unit
Product or service that produced this file. Used by many systems (e.g., VAT). Version number can be included or extended.
Particular use for which file was generated.
The default currency related to the amount can be entered here instead of the XBRL instance specified way, especially important in multi-currency situations. Recommend ISO 4217 coding

The date/time a period has been closed for activity. If this is present with a nill value (xsi:nill="true") then the period is not closed.
Parent for entry headers/journal entry headers.
Date this entry was posted (validated) to the general ledger. May not represent the date of accounting significance which is represented by 'postingDate'.
Initials/name of operator originally entering.
Identification for the last person modifying this entry before posting.
Represents the actual date/time of entry into computer (automated from system date, often misrepresented by changing system clock). Posting dates are maintained separately.
Identifier of person who created or originated or is otherwise responsible for the entry.

Source journal. The code of the journal in which the entry is processed. 
The code must be a unique indication for a journal and is selected from the following enumerated list:
cd      cash disbursements (sending cheques to vendors)
cr      cash receipts (receiving cheques from others)
fa      fixed assets
gi      giro/other bank adjustments
gj      general journal
im      inventory management
jc      job cost
pj      purchase journal (liabilities from purchases)
pl      payroll journal
sj      sales journal
se      standard entries
ud      user defined
ot      other sources of entries

Source journal (full description of general journal, payroll journal, accountant entries). A more easily readable journal indication. The most common journals are: Purchases, Sales, Cash, and General Journal.
One of the following enumerated list: adjusting, budget, comparative, external-accountant, standard, passed-adjusting, eliminating, proposed, recurring, reclassifying, simulated, tax, other
Origin of entry: accrual, manual entry, imported entry, exchange gain or loss
Identifier within source journal
Description of entry described by this entry header (e.g. Opening Balance)

Entry Qualifier - An enumerated field that qualifies the type of entry, specifically useful for general ledger and trial balance environments when it is important to state the values represented are summarized as of the reporting date - opening or closing balances. In accounting systems, this is often known as BBF (balance brought forward.) Permitted values are: standard, balance-brought-forward and other.
Free format description of the entry qualifier

Code for posting to period, e.g., period 1-13, based on codes in an accounting period file. We do not recommend that software vendors export here, but suggest providing period end numbers for the buckets. Possibilities W1 through W53, M1 through M13, Q1-Q4. Developers and others creating output files are encouraged to supply an actual end date.
ID for a batch for this group of entries
Description of this batch
The total number of entries.
The total of all debit amounts.
The total of all credit amounts.
Enumerated field with possible values of permanent, temporary or none indicating the type of difference between book and tax accounting methods. Omission of this field is equivalent to "none"
Informs destination ledger this is an intracompany entry which eliminates in consolidation
Start of period covered by associated budgetScenario
End of period covered by associated budgetScenario
Text related to budgetScenario
Code for a budget scenario identifier (such as PB for 'preliminary budget', or RB for 'revised budget', or other identifier for entryType)
Code associated with the calculation formula: e.g. (D)ivide by number of periods, (T)otal for period given
For standard, reversing, master, cancelling or other entries an ID associated with those entries.
Description to accompany standard or recurring ID

For standard or recurring journals, how often entry may be made: every frequencyInterval frequencyUnit, such as every 7 (interval) days (unit) or every 1 (interval) quarter (unit). This field represents the interval.

For standard or recurring journals, how often entry may be made: every frequencyInterval frequencyUnit, such as every 7 (interval) days (unit) or every 1 (interval) quarter (unit). This field represents the unit.
Number of times that the recurring entry will repeat
Date next repeated or standard posted
Date last repeated or standard posted
For standard or recurring journals, stop date/time for repetitive entry.
Should entry be reversed?
Date this entry should be reversed
Unique reference for the entry - a numeric counter
Parent for entry detail
Identifier for a particular entry detail
Unique reference for the line - a numeric counter

Tuple: parent container for account numbers and identifiers. No entry is made here, but each detail line may have multiple accounts assigned to it for reporting in different GAAPs, offsetting accounts in Japan, passing along information to consolidation systems about local versus consolidating accounts, etc. For example, the account 4783HG-QOWI-192837-1000 may be expressed so:
/account/accountMainID 1000
/account/accountMainDescription Cash
/account/accountSub/accountSubID 4783HG
/account/accountSub/accountSubDescription Department
/account/accountSub/accountSubID QOWI
/account/accountSub/accountSubDescription Branch
/account/accountSub/accountSubID 192837
/account/accountSub/accountSubDescription Division

Main account - the code used to identify the accounting bucket the entry has been assigned to. Examples might be 1000 for Cash, 567GAAZ for Sales Expense or Z for tax payments. Identifiers such as department, branch, division, manager, or other modifiers are noted in the Subaccount area. Before needing to post, account is not necessary. Posting to the general ledger almost always requires an entry here.
Description of accountMainID - the human readable describer that accompanies the code used in accountMainID

Account type - FASB Concepts 6 and similar international designs. When xbrlInfo is used to associated other XBRL reporting items, this field is more suited to representing existing systems (audit) than data interchange. Enumerated as: asset, liability, equity, income, gain, expense, loss, contr-to-equity, distr-from-equity, comprehensive-income, other.
Free format description of the account classification
Roll up item from child natural account to parent natural account.

Code related to usage for account aggregate - Consolidating, European, IFRS, Offsetting, Primary, Tax, USGAAP, Japanese, Other. Japanese companies will use this for the tax required offsetting entry. If left blank, assumes default accounting method for company.
Description of usage for aggregate account
Type of account. Enumerated as: account, bank, employee, customer, job, vendor, measurable, statistical, other.
Free format description of the account type
For this entry, the method of accounting represented - from: accrual, cash, modified cash, modified accrual, encumbrance, special methods, hybrid methods, other
Free format description of the entry accounting method
For this entry, the reporting purpose represented - from book, tax, management, statutory, other
Free format description of the entry accounting method purpose
Tuple to hold multiple accountSubIDs and Descriptions
The description that accompanies accountSubID belongs here.
Where the primary account was placed in accountMainID, the code used for each profit center, division, business unit, fund, program, branch, project, class, su-class or other modifier is placed here.

Type of sub-account - profit center, division, business unit, fund, program, branch, project, class, su-class or other modifier is placed here. For example:: Accountability center: Business unit: Class:Department: Project: Fund: Program:Job: Profit center: Branch: Setup class: Division: Unit
Tuple for showing the detail necessary to roll up from one segment (type of subaccount) to another.)
Subaccount NUMBER this subaccount rolls up to - see also subaccount type it rolls up to.
The describer of the segment this subaccount rolls up to.
Used for representing descriptions of reporting trees.
For partial allocations of amounts to different parents, the percentage of a child that will be allocated to a parent.
Boolean to indicate whether the account is active (="true") or inactive (="false")

This field (amount) represents the primary monetary amount related to the  subject of the entryDetail line. 
There is one primary monetary amount per entryDetail structure.
It may, for example, represent the amount of one line of a journal entry, the balance on a document, or the extended amount of a line item on an invoice. 
Amount is not required if detailed entry is used for non-financial work and other elements are populated, in particular measurableQuantity. 
The amount field is a signed number (either positive or negative itself) and used in conjunction with a separate signOfAmount and a separate debitCreditCode, which together are considered for understanding the monetary amount. 
The unit of measure is determined by amountCurrency if present, and by the default or home currency if amountCurrency is not present.
The currency related to the amount can be entered here instead of the XBRL instance specified way, especially important in multi-currency situations. \nRecommend ISO 4217 coding.
Amount in original (as opposed to home) currency, for multi-currency tracking.
The currency used to track original, as opposed to home, amounts. Recommended ISO 4217 coding.
Exchange rate at time of original transaction (expressed as national currency divided by original currency)
Date of exchange rate used to record the original transaction.
Source of Exchange Rate - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
Comment about exchange rate used for recording original transaction.
If triangulation is used, amount in triangulation currency, for multi-currency tracking. Debit is entered as positive, credit as negative.
The currency used for triangulation, if used. May often be EUR or USD. Recommended ISO 4217 coding.
Exchange rate between national currency and triangulation currency at time of original transaction (expressed as national currency divided by triangulation currency)

column6: Amount Original Triangulation Exchange Rate Source
column7: Source of Exchange Rate for triangulation amount at time of original transaction - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg

column6: Amount Original Triangulation Exchange Rate Type
column7: Type of Exchange Rate for triangulation amount at time of original transaction - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.
Exchange rate between original currency and triangulation currency at time of original transaction (expressed as original currency divided by triangulation currency)
Source of Exchange Rate for triangulation from original currency to triangulation currency at time of original transaction - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
Type of Exchange Rate for triangulation from original currency to triangulation currency at time of original transaction - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.

Sign of amount; provides 4 possible fields only when used in conjunction with debitCreditCode; primarily used for correcting entries so total debits and credits after an entry error are not inflated. D + increase DebitsD - decrease debitsC + decreases creditC - increases credit
Optional identifier of whether the amount is a (D)ebit, a (C)redit or Undefined

At the detail level, this represents the accounting significance date. No matter what date the document is received, entered, or posted, this signifies the accounting date of the entry. If you want to see the financial results for March 5, 2002 and this entry is given that date, the entry will be part of the results for March 5, 2002. This is different from the postedDate found at the entryHeader level. If you want the accounting significance to be a particular date, it goes here. A single entry could represent multiple dates, but would only be posted on one date.
A boolean like entry that indicates whether an entryDetail line has been provided solely to provide additional details and that tools should not consider the amount in postings.
A code that is tied to the Enterprise's allocation system.

Section to provide additional information related to home currencies that differ from original currencies and related exchange rates - typically this will be used to record exchange rates and amounts in currencies and/or on dates other than those of the original transaction. This structure allows recording of exchange rates using a third currency as a triangulation currency. This is often EUR but is not restricted to being so. This structure may be repeated as many times as necessary to record amounts in foreign currencies on the same or different dates.
Date of exchange rate (other than original transaction date) on which amount is expressed as amountRestatedAmount or amountTriangulationAmount
The amount in the foreign currency identified by amountRestatedCurrency as of multicurrencyDetailExchangeRateDate.
The currency in which amountRestatedAmount is expressed. Recommended ISO 4217 coding.
Exchange rate used to convert amountRestatedAmount as of multicurrencyDetailExchangeRateDate (expressed as national currency divided by foreign currency)
Source of Exchange Rate for restated amount - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
Type of Exchange Rate for restated amount - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.
The amount in the triangulation currency identified by amountTriangulationCurrency as of multicurrencyDetailExchangeRateDate.
The currency used for tringulation between amountRestatedCurrency and the home currency. Recommended ISO 4217 coding.
Exchange rate used to convert amountTriangulationAmount as of multicurrencyDetailExchangeRateDate (expressed as national currency divided by triangulation currency)
Source of Exchange Rate for triangulation amount - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
Type of Exchange Rate for triangulation amount - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.
Exchange rate used to convert from amountRestatedAmount to amountTriangulationAmount as of multicurrencyDetailExchangeRateDate (expressed as foreign currency divided by triangulation currency)
Source of Exchange Rate for converting between foreign currency and triangulation currency - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
Type of Exchange Rate for converting between foreign currency and triangulation currency - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.
Comment describing the enclosing multicurrencyDetail tuple's contents. May include reason for recording additional exchange rates other than that used at the time of the original transaction.
Identification for customer, vendor, or employee.

An enumerated field describing the original source document, with check, debit-memo, credit-memo, finance-charge, invoice, order-customer, order-vendor, payment-other, reminder, tegata, voucher, shipment, receipt, manual-adjustment, other.
Free format description of the document type
Invoice Type  (self-billed, ePoS enumerated values)
Invoice, check, voucher, or other source document identifier

Document number of primary invoice number, used to offset payments, debits and credits; for an invoice, usually the same as the documentNumber. When calculating open balance on an invoice, or open amount on payments in advance or not fully applied, this permits calculation of the open item.
Internal reference for the document above; number assigned internally to track the document
Date (and less likely in the paper world but possible in the e-world, time) on actual document (invoice, voucher, check date). Other dates control posting information.
Date/time document was noted as received (if necessary). Represents actual date received. Posting dates are maintained separately.
Is this entry chargeable to client, reimbursable? Used by some systems to indicate that account on posting/validation should be posted to a customer or vendor's account.
Document location as URI, file name or other reference. Alternatively, text of document can be placed here.
Method used or to be used to make the payment

deferred: although entered, it cannot be posted until a later time
posted: already posted
proposed: a proposed item that must be approved
simulated: a simulated item, for what-if
tax: a tax-specific entry
unposted:entered but not yet posted or validated
cancelled:entered and later cancelled
other:other status - should be described in postingStatusDescription
Free format description of the posting status

This will roll up to XBRL reporting information - this is a parent - repeatable so that the same item can be reported through many taxonomies. Care should be taken to consider what happens if people post to the same account but different XBRL elements.
Indicates that the information being given is beginning_balance, ending_balance, period_change.
Associated XBRL element or XML element within an XML taxonomy - mapping to an XBRL concept.

Discount/payment terms.

Parent for information regarding measurable items associated with the enclosing entryDetail line. Primary area used for holding performance measures. Based on needs for tracking inventory transactional detail, but suitable for anything assigned to an "account", "reporting bucket" or "code". Can be used to track any movements.

Code for measurable item including BP - Business process, FA - Fixed asset/Capitalized item, IN - Inventory, KPI - Metric, NT - Intangible, SP - Supplies, SV-P - Service by employee, vendor or contractor, SV-M - Service by equipment/machinery, OT - Other
Free format description of the measurable code
Category of the measurable
Internal inventory part or SKU number or other code identifier for the measurable.
URI or other identifier for schema with which measurable ID can be validated
Second identifier (such as vendor's item number)
URI or other identifier for schema with which measurable ID Other can be validated
Text description of measurable (e.g. inventory item or other identifier)
Number of units in this transaction; for non-monetary calculations; can be square footage, number of people, etc.
Field that can represent grading, inspection codes, ratings and other qualifiers to properly capture PKI/Balanced Scorecard information
Description of unit: e.g. each, case, dozen, etc. ISO standard coding recommended.
Per unit price of the measurable. Although one might expect that measurableQuantity * measurableCostPerUnit = amount, this is not mandated except by external rules sets.
Start time of the duration being measured
End time of the duration being measured
Boolean to indicate whether the measurable is active (="true") or inactive (="false")

Tuple for holding job related information, separate from jobs represented in account identifier. Would probably only have one jobinfo tuple for each entry line, but there may be a need to express more than one.

Associated job number or code. This could be built into the account, but many systems maintain a separate job coding system. Use primarily if job identification is a separate system, and not considered part of the chart of accounts.
Description of job
Job code, phase, activity. Allows greater granularity than a simple job number. Although the core only reaches down from job to phases, this can be customized to extend down to cost codes.
Description of Job code, phase, activity
Boolean to indicate whether the job is active (="true") or inactive (="false")
Parent for information related to depreciation, mortgages, etc.
Jurisdiction (e.g. federal, state, local): e.g. US Federal, Province of Qubec, other identifier. Enumerated as: F, federal, S, state, L, local, other.

Type of depreciation method: used for information about the loan percentage for loan or the depreciation method. This is used for informational purposes only. Examples of entries are "20%", "5 year DDB" (Double Declining Balance).
Length of life in number of periods.
Description of each item related to depreciation, mortgage, loan, credit facility, etc.
Start of the applicable period of each item related to depreciation, mortgage, loan, credit facility, etc.
End of the applicable period of each item related to depreciation, mortgage, loan, credit facility, etc.
Amount of a cost or fee charged for a mortgage, loan, credit facility, etc.

An enumerated code to identify the inventory, fixed asset or other measurable class. Enumerated as: raw material, work-in-process, finished goods, assemblies, supplies, land, building, machinery, furniture, vehicles, other.
Free format description associated with gl-ehm:measurableClassID to provide specialization or clarification for the enumerated value of other.
An enumerated code for the inventory (or other measurable) costing method. Enumerated as: LIFO, FIFO, average, weighted-average, standard-cost, tax-basis, book-basis, other.
Free format description associated with gl-ehm:costingMethodCode to provide specialization of clarification for the enumerated value of other.

Enter a relevant location for this item. Format can be either:
- Degrees, minutes, and seconds (DMS): 4124'12.2"N 210'26.5"E
- Degrees and decimal minutes (DMM): 41 24.2028, 2 10.4418
- Decimal degrees (DD): 41.40338, 2.17403
Tuple for holding information about serial numbers or lots (batches). As a tuple, this permits multiple serial numbers or multiple lot number batches within a single gl-cor:measurable structure.

Is this item tracked by serial numbers or lot numbers? A serial number is usually a unique number assigned to a single; a lot or batch number is provided when a batch of items is fungible but must be differentiated from similar items from other batches. Enumerated indicator for serial or lot items. Enumeration are: serial, lot, other, neither. If not included within the tuple, neither is assumed.

Free format description associated with gl-ehm:serialLotCode to provide specialization and especially to provide clarification for the enumerated value of other in serialLotCode. Examples might be batch or group.
The holder for that actual serial number or lot (batch) number/code assigned to an item or a batch of items.
A field for holding the next expected serial or lot number to be given to future assignments, or for chaining between already assigned items.
The quantity of units in this particular batch. Unit of measure is the gl-bus:measurableUnitofMeasure.
The quantity of units in this batch on inception.
The remaining quantity of units from the original batch; may be the same as the quantity in this batch or include other batches from the same original batch.
Date of manufacture or creation.
Expiration date of the batch.
Manufacturer of the item (serial) or items (lot/batch).
A name or description of the items in the lot or batch.
If the items are covered by warranty, when that warranty covered will begin or has begun.
If the items are covered by warranty, when that warranty covered will end or ended.
Warranty period  numeric portion; for a 30 day warranty period, the 30 would go here, and the day would go in gl-ehm:serialLotWarrantyPeriodUnit.

Warrant period  time or cycle unit portion. Values from the XBRL Unit Registry (www.xbrl.org/utr/utr.xml) are suggested where possible. Examples might include: H (hours), D (days), M (months), Y (years), machine cycles, km (kilometers).
The vendor providing warranty; this may differ from the manufacturer.
Contract or document information related to the warranty, such as a contract number and date or a URL with more information.
Free format text related to the serial number or lot.
Tuple for holding tax related information
Name of the relevant tax authority
Tax table code used by the relevant tax authority
Description of tax authority
Amount of taxes
Basis for taxation
[DEPRECATED. taxExchangeRate should be used one in gl-muc pallette] Amount for foreign currency tracking in original currency
Percent rate for VAT or other taxes normally a number between 0 and 1.0 - e.g. 50% is represented as 0.5
A class or category of taxes
Additional text/code for exemption reasons or other comments.
If the tax is in a foreign currency, the amount of tax in that currency
If the tax is in a foreign currency, that currency
If the tax is in a foreign currency, the date or date and time of the exchange rate used
If the tax is in a foreign currency, the exchange rate used expressed as national currency divided by foreign currency
If the tax is in a foreign currency, source of exchange rate - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
If the tax is in a foreign currency, type of exchange rate - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.
If the tax is in a foreign currency, comment about exchange rate used
If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, the amount of that tax in the triangulation currency
If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, the triangulation currency
If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, the exchange rate used expressed as national currency divided by triangulation currency
If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, source of exchange rate - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg
If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, type of exchange rate - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.
If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used,  the exchange rate used expressed as foreign currency divided by triangulation currency

column6: Tax Foreign Triangulation Exchange Rate Source
column7: If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, source of exchange rate - for example, Reuters, Bloomberg

column6: Tax Foreign Triangulation Exchange Rate Type
column7: If the tax is in a foreign currency and triangulation is used, type of exchange rate - for example, spot rate, forward contract etc.

Signifies that an item has been cleared, finished, finalized. When checking accounts are called for, the tick or letter showing this was done appears in this field. Can also be used for identifying that the original document against which a payment or DR/CR memo applies has been reconciled.
Balance remaining on the document

Unique Consignment Reference or UCR. An "origin to destination" reference code for international consignments, developed in cooperation with the World Customs Organization and EAN International (EAN). (http://www.wcoomd.org/ie/EN/press/UCR_new_e.pdf)

A tool to capture the flow of related documents in the business process. Some needs of end users require a greater history of the documents that are associated with a transaction, especially in the VAT audit area. Contains a repetitive structure of related documents.

Originating document type  check, debit-memo, credit-memo, finance-charge, invoice, order-customer, order-vendor, payment-other, reminder, tegata, voucher, shipment, receipt, manual-adjustment, other.
Originating document number
Originating document date
Originating document identifier type. Enumerated as: C, customer, E, employee, V, vendor, O, other, I, salesperson-internal, X, salesperson-external, N, contractor.
Originating document identifier code
Originating document identifier tax code
